metadata.title: Mallet Finger
description: Mallet finger is a deformity of the finger caused by either a finger extensor tendon rupture/laceration or an avulsion fracture of the distal phalanx at the insertion of the terminal extensor tendon.(9)Mallet finger is characterized by the flexion deformity at DIP joint and the inability to extend the joint actively(1) –Tendinous or soft tissue mallet finger refers to mallet finger caused by an extensor tendon rupture/laceration(9) –Bony mallet finger refers to the avulsion fracture of the distal phalanx(9)

Classification of mallet injuries according to Doyle(1) –Type I – closed injury, with or without small dorsal avulsion fracture –Type II – open injury (laceration) –Type III – open injury (deep abrasion involving skin and tendon substance) –Type IV – mallet fractures -A – distal phalanx physeal injury (pediatric) -B – fracture fragment involving 20–50%  of articular surface (adult) -C – fracture fragment involving more than 50% of articular surface (adult)

An additional type of injury (type V) has been proposed by Zhang et al.(15,24) –This injury is a combined bony and tendon (double level) mallet injury in which there is a combination of a fracture at the base of the distal phalanx and a laceration/rupture of the tendon, with or without a bony fragment in the tendon end –Zhang et al. propose that this level of injury would require surgical intervention

ICD-10 codes.M20.019: mallet finger of unspecified finger(s) (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes.)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific issues or information is identified regarding reimbursement
presentation signs and symptoms: Pain, swelling, and tenderness at the dorsum of DIP joint(1)
Loss of active extension ROM at DIP joint(10)
Decreased extensor strength at DIP joint
Flexion deformity develops due to an extension lag, where the DIP joint is in flexion (also known as “drop finger”)
Impaired fine motor skills –Disability of affected hand in some ADLs Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician
Passive flexion of the DIP joint is avoided until the second week after initiation of night splinting(9)
The initial physical exam is usually limited to inspection and gentle palpation, with a delay in the ROM and strength testing
Obtain physician orders to initiate ROM and strength testing

causes: The usual mechanism of injury is a suddenly forced flexion of the extended DIP joint due to blunt trauma, such as froma ball hitting the fingertip or thumb (e.g., “baseball finger”); the mechanism can also be less forceful, such as duringhousehold activities (e.g., making a bed), self-care  activities (e.g., putting on socks), or work activities(2,17,18)
In children the cause is trauma, such as a crush in a door(2)
Laceration of the tendon or crush injuries are less common causes(1)
In rheumatoid arthritis a swan neck deformity always results in a mallet deformity as well(2)
pathogenesis ,,: Disruption of the “extensor mechanism” (i.e., terminal tendon or dorsum attachment of the extensor pollicis of thumb)produces a flexion deformity at the DIP joint
Most cases are closed injuries. However, the skin may be opened by laceration or avulsion of a bony fragment from thedistal phalanx
Discontinuity of tendon produces a hammer-like  (mallet) deformity because the DIP joint cannot be extended
Hyperflexion may fracture the distal phalanx

Untreated mallet finger may progress to a swan neck deformity because of the proximal and dorsal migration of theextensor mechanism causing proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint hyperextension–For additional information on swan neck deformity, see  Clinical Review ... Finger Extensor Tendon Injuries:Nonoperative Treatment   CINAHL Topic ID Number: T904389
risk factors: High-energy  etiology is more common in young males, whereas lower-energy  injuries are seen in older adult women(2)
Activities and sports that involve catching a ball or objectare a common mechanism for younger individuals(2)

overall contraindications precautions: Obtain specific orders for evaluation and treatment from referring physician

Patients who undergo surgical repair are at risk for pin-site  infection and osteomyelitis. Evaluate pin sites at each visit and educate the patient as to the signs and symptoms of infection (fever, increased warmth to touch, redness surrounding incision, exudate, severe pain)

Orthosis use Adhere to the physician’s protocol for orthosis use. Continuous immobilization in full extension or slight (5–10°) hyperextension for 6–8 weeks is common practice. Healing time likely varies from case to case. An additional, interlocking dorsal component holding the PIP at 40 to 45o flexion to reposition the lateral bands can be incorporated into the orthosis(4) There may be an increased risk of skin complications when a prefabricated orthosis is used(18) –Based on the findings of a systematic review that there is moderate-quality  evidence that the risk of developing skin complications is 3 times greater with the use of a prefabricated orthosis in the treatment of mallet finger No DIP joint motion during the period of orthosis immobilization. Caution patient that flexion at DIP joint during first 6 weeks will disrupt healing and likely require an additional 6 weeks of splinting Use an aluminum foam splint if there is significant swelling Avoid blanching of skin or vascular compromise of distal phalanx when the orthosis is in use Allow free movement of all uninjured finger joints Check skin condition daily Provide a second orthosis for showering or hand washing Caution patient not to change orthosis without assistance and instruct patient/caregiver in the correct technique to safely don and doff orthosis Use of taping (e.g., elastic tape, steri-strips)  to support the DIP position when donning/doffing the orthosis may be helpful(21)  Fabrication of customized mallet splints using three-dimensional printing has been reported as being an alternative to other available splinting options for mallet finger(27)
High risk of volar subluxation at DIP joint in injuries with a large avulsed bony fragment may require primary repair or K-wire  fixation of the fragment(4)
Tendon failure may occur if DIP joint flexion rehabilitation is started too soon or progressed too rapidly
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When did the symptoms begin? What type of trauma was involved? Did the injury occur during sports? Is dominant hand affected? Was PIP joint involved as well? Were any other injuries sustained to the hand or upper extremity? Was there a fracture? Were there any complications up to this point? How long has the patient been in an orthosis?

course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Finger imaging studies may include:

Three-view  radiographs are needed to differentiate the types of mallet finger. Tendinous mallet will show soft tissue swellingand bony mallet will show avulsion at the dorsal base of the distal phalanx (best seen on lateral view)(11)
Imaging studies may help diagnose the extent of injury(9)
Radiographic studies to assess bony involvement
Ultrasound or MRI to assess tendon integrity or for presence of foreign bodies
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any noted aggravating or easing factors
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of awakenings/night related to the condition
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to the physician (e.g., a sudden increase in swelling)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ___________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any preexisting hand or finger disability? Any family history of nontraumatic mallet finger?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, other upper extremity disorders (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome, trigger finger)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Is the patient planning on returning to sport? If the patient will be returning to work, does his or her job require high functional dexterity?
social and occupational history.living environment: Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from the physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document the particular orthosis that the patient is currently using –The Stack mallet finger splint keeps the DIP in extension but permits active flexion at the PIP joint.(5) Dorsal aluminum foam splint (placed dorsally or volarly), Abouna metal splint, and custom-fabricated  thermoplastic orthoses may also be used(1) –Assess the need for any adaptive devices the patient may require for independence with ADLs
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Confirm that fingertip blood flow appears adequate, and skin is not blanched or discoloredAssess dermatomes and myotomes of the affected extremityMeasure finger circumference to assess swellingAssess ligament stability and joint mobility of DIP joint when appropriate
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –After immobilization period is discontinued (often at about 6 to 8 weeks) and physician orders permit assessment of strength, use manual muscle testing (MMT) to assess isometric flexion and extension strength with the DIP positioned in full extension –Assess hand grip strength and tip pinch strength with dynamometers –Assess functional power grip and pinch grip of the injured finger and compare to the contralateral side and norms for sex and age
observation inspection palpation includi: Check for loose (avulsed) body at DIP joint in acute cases
Assess pain and tenderness using V AS
Assess for signs of infection and skin irritation from splint/orthosis use
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active and passive ROM of bilateral digits and wrist, with particular attention to DIP joint. Follow referring physician’s orders regarding ROM assessment after splint/orthosis is discontinued(typically 6 to 8 weeks post injury) –Normal active ROM at DIP joint is 0° extension and 80–90° flexion –Some degree of residual extension lag is not uncommon following treatment(1) –Assess the opening and closing of the injured handAssess ability to grasp and functionally use items such as a fork, comb, or pencil with affected finger/hand (during or after splintage). Assess ability to dress and perform other fine motor/ dexterity ADLs. The Manual Abilities Measure–36  (MAM-36)  can be used to assess functional upper extremity use(19,20)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess sensation of the fingertip to light touch, temperature, and pinprick
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Use the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder,and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure for outcome assessment. For more information on the DASH, see  Clinical Review ... Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) OutcomeT903177

contraindications precautions: Over an area of nerve regrowth
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Hypertension—cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Hypersensitivity to cold or a personal aversion to cold
Presence of or the tendency for hemorrhage or edema
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below for the use of modalities is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Mallet finger injury/pain and swelling; decreased ROM and strength at DIP joint; reduced finger function; splint DIP joint continuously for 6–8 weeks(4)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule outan avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon (suspect if the patient is unable to flex joint actively) Fracture with dislocation Jammed finger(10) Rheumatoid arthritis (post-surgery)(10)  Osteoarthritis(10) Swan-neck  deformity(10) DIP joint dislocation Peripheral nerve injury Trigger finger (stenosing tenosynovitis)
prognosis: There is no definitive evidence that outcomes are better with surgical repair than with splinting/orthosis use(7,12)
The findings of a systematic review demonstrated that older age, more edema, and decreased patient compliance with the treatment protocol all negatively impact the degree of extension gained(17)

Skin irritation is a risk associated with splinting/orthosis use, but does not negatively impact outcomes. Individuals have reported negligible pain, minimal difficulties with ADLs and work, and relatively high satisfaction with finger function and treatment outcome (7)
Rate of complications following surgical management is approximately 14.5%; these include nail deformities and infection(12)

Healing and reattachment of the tendon occurs in most cases with splinting of the DIP joint in full extension for 6 to 8 weeks.(10)The likelihood of successful healing may be reduced if there is a delay in treatment, but this remains controversial(7)

Without surgical repair in cases in which more than one-third  of an articular surface is affected and/or when palmar subluxation occurs, the patient is at risk for developing early osteoarthritis, swan-neck  deformity, and persistent DIP joint stiffness(12)

The authors of a 2018 systematic review found no difference in outcome based on time from injury to presentation; however, this review excluded studies focused only on chronic injury. The authors contend that the impact of delay in treatment remains controversial(7)

At a hospital in Scotland a self-care  protocol was initiated in which patients with mallet injuries were managed in the emergency department (ED) with no additional routine follow-up(16) –At the time of the ED visit, the patients were provided with a splint and an information leaflet with information about splint use and skin hygiene. They were also given the number to a helpline for any follow-up  questions or concerns –Forty-seven  patients were contacted at a mean follow-up  of 322 days and had a mean Quick DASH score of 2.27. Nine of the patients used the helpline and were satisfied with the response –One common issue with this approach is a need for a second splint/orthosis when the initial swelling has subsided –Additional studies have shown that this approach does not result in reported treatment failures or patient dissatisfaction(25,26)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthopedic surgeon for tendon failure Hand therapist for cases complicated by other hand injuries Occupational therapist for ADL training
treatment summary: There are no high-quality  randomized trials to guide practitioners as to which splint/orthosis is more effective or when surgery is indicated for acute mallet finger injuries(3) –Based on a 2004 Cochrane systematic review –All trials had methodological limitations –Three trials evaluated various types of finger splints and one trial compared surgical fixation techniques –Conservative treatment appears to be as effective as surgery in the majority of studies

A South African occupational therapist proposes the use of kinesiology tape in conjunction with a thermoplastic orthosis to shorten the immobilization phase(14) –Sixteen subjects followed the protocol developed by the author, in which patients are immobilized only for 4 weeks vs the 6 to 8 weeks typically recommended –Kinesiology tape, an elastic-like  tape, is applied to the affected joint to limit DIP flexion while holding the joint in extension. A thermoplastic orthosis is used in conjunction with the taping technique for the first 4 weeks of the immobilization period  –Weeks 4–6:Known  as the graded protective immobilization period, require the subject to continue with the kinesiology tape while using the orthosis at night only –Weeks 6–8:Kinesiology  tape is discontinued and active ROM and light ADLs are encouraged –Week 8: Subjects can return to sport without any activity limitations,and full active ROM is attained
Use of a steri-strip  to hold the DIP joint in extension in conjunction with the application of a circumferential DIP extension orthosis has been proposed by a group of therapists in Canada(21)

Rehabilitation of DIP joint function after the splinting period involves progressive therapeutic exercises to restore ROM and strength and functional training as needed to restore finger ability in ADLs. Prescription and application of devices/ equipment should be done per physician orders –The DIP joint is usually splinted in full extension at all times for at least 6 weeks –Daytime splinting may be discontinued after 6 to 8 weeks,whereas nighttime splinting continues for 2 more weeks(3) –A separate splint/orthosis should be used for showering or hand washing
Return to play is permitted during splintage if the sport can be played safely and effectively without putting the splinted DIP joint (or athlete) at increased risk of re-injury(8)

The authors of a survey of British hand therapists found that hand therapists’ provision of splinting and guidance for ROM are important to achieve good therapeutic outcomes and that therapists should follow evidence-based  guidelines for care(22)

The authors of a study conducted in South Korea found that poor health literacy (i.e., poor ability to process and understand health information to make appropriate health decisions) is correlated with greater extensor lag and treatment dissatisfaction in mallet finger injury.(23) Providing patient education and confirming the patient’s understanding of the information provided may help to improve health literacy . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Pain, swelling, and tenderness on dorsum of distal phalanxResolve pain, swelling, and tendernessPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Rest, ice, compression, elevation (RICE) therapy may help relieve pain and swelling in acute injury. Retrograde massage _ _ Electrotherapeutic modalities _ Evidence is lacking to support the use of electrotherapeutic modalitiesPhysical agents may be used as necessary to relieve pain and swelling pending physician approvalProvide the patient with written instructions on the correct application of splint/ orthosis, proper care of finger, and RICE techniques(23)  Weakness in DIP joint function _ Inability to extend DIP joint to 0°Normal DIP joint functionTherapeutic exercises _ Begin gentle assisted active ROM after a continuous splinting period of at least 6 weeks,and physician orders are received _ _ If no significant extensor lag (more than 10°) is evident, continue with slow active ROM to 10– 15° DIP flexion, several times daily, and progress by 10– 15° flexion per week. Progress to passive ROM and gentle resistance exercises _ _ Passive flexion of the DIP joint often is avoided until the second week of nighttime-only splinting(9) _ _ Functional training _ Introduce finger prehension and dexterity coordination exercises as per physician ordersGradual progression of the intensity of exercises as deemed appropriate (and ordered by a physician) until normal functionality is restoredProvide patient and family/caregivers with written instructions regarding therapeutic exercises and functional activities that can be performed at home(23) .

maintenance or prevention: Follow-up  exams should be performed at 2-week  intervals until the injury is healed. Follow-up  radiographs need to be taken for bony mallet finger injuries. Night splinting may or may not be recommended for 2 to 3 additional weeks after tendon has healed(11) In a 2014 RCT in the United States of the efficacy of night splinting following 6 to 8 weeks of continuous splinting, researchers concluded that night splinting did not improve outcomes of extensor lag, disability, or overall patient satisfaction(13) –Fifty-one  subjects were placed randomly in the no-splint group or the intervention group (night splint). Outcome measures were taken after subjects in the intervention group wore the splint for 4 continuous weeks -There are methodologic limitations with this study that should be considered when interpreting its findings, including small sample size and inconsistent treatment adherence –Results indicated that subjects with worse initial extensor lags had poorer results compared to those with less of an extensor lag following the night splinting –Final degree of extensor lag correlated with age, DIP flexionand extension ROM, and degree of extensor lag after the period of 6 to 8 weeks of continuous splinting
Continue the prescribed home program of therapeutic exercises and functional training until normal finger function is restored
